description: A lesser-known pest, likely a type of insect affecting specific crops, characterized by its small size and potential to damage plant tissues.
A species of whitefly with spiny features, known for feeding on plant sap and transmitting plant viruses, often found on citrus crops.
A genus of moths whose larvae feed on grapevines and other plants, causing defoliation and reduced crop yield.
A citrus aphid that feeds on the sap of citrus trees, leading to curled leaves, stunted growth, and sooty mold growth.
A green mirid bug that damages a variety of crops, including cotton and fruits, by piercing plant tissues and sucking sap.
A fruit fly species that lays eggs in fruits, particularly citrus, causing rot and significant agricultural losses.
Small flies that target beet crops, laying eggs on leaves and causing spotting and damage to foliage.
A caterpillar with dark, hairy features, known for feeding on a variety of plants and causing defoliation.
A tiny mite species that feeds on citrus and other plants, causing stippling and reduced photosynthesis.
A red wax scale insect that infests trees and shrubs, secreting a waxy coating and weakening plants by sap extraction.
A moth whose larvae bore into plant stems, particularly affecting fruit trees and causing structural damage.
A circular scale insect that attacks citrus and ornamental plants, leading to yellowing leaves and reduced vigor.
A green leafhopper that feeds on plant sap, potentially transmitting plant pathogens and causing leaf yellowing.
A family of leafhoppers known for their jumping ability, feeding on plant sap and spreading viral diseases.
A grape erineum mite that causes abnormal growths (erinea) on grape leaves, reducing photosynthesis.
The oriental fruit fly, a major pest of fruits and vegetables, laying eggs that lead to maggot infestations.
A genus of gall midges whose larvae induce gall formation on plants, disrupting growth and development.
A weevil species that bores into seeds and stems, causing damage to crops like nuts and legumes.
A leafhopper that feeds on grapevines and other plants, causing stippling and reduced fruit quality.
A common cricket that feeds on crops and seedlings, particularly in fields, causing irregular damage.
A moth whose adults pierce fruit to feed on juice, leading to rot and secondary infections.
A small fly that induces gall formation on plants, disrupting nutrient flow and growth.
The cottony cushion scale, a pest of citrus and ornamentals, secreting a white waxy coating and weakening plants.
A caterpillar pest of indigo and other crops, feeding on leaves and causing significant defoliation.
A weevil that bores into jute stems, weakening the plant and reducing fiber quality.
A small sap-sucking insect that affects jute plants, causing curled leaves and stunted growth.
A hairy caterpillar that feeds on jute leaves, leading to defoliation and reduced yield.
A red mite that infests jute plants, causing stippling and yellowing of leaves.
A looping caterpillar that feeds on jute foliage, creating holes and reducing plant vigor.
A pest that girdles jute stems, disrupting nutrient transport and causing plant death.
A stick-like insect that blends into jute plants, feeding on sap and weakening stems.
A leafhopper species that feeds on plant sap, potentially transmitting diseases to crops.
A beetle that feeds on leaves, creating holes and reducing photosynthesis in various crops.
A family of slug-like caterpillars that feed on foliage, often causing severe defoliation.
A swarming grasshopper that devastates crops by consuming leaves, stems, and grains.
A superfamily of locusts and grasshoppers known for their destructive feeding habits.
The spotted lanternfly, a sap-feeding pest that weakens trees and promotes mold growth.
A leafhopper with a flattened beak, feeding on mango trees and potentially spreading pathogens.
A soft-bodied insect covered in white wax, feeding on plant sap and excreting honeydew.
A family of plant bugs that pierce and suck sap from crops, causing wilting and distortion.
A mealybug species that infests palms and other plants, weakening them through sap extraction.
The citrus red mite, a pest that damages citrus leaves, causing stippling and drop.
A swallowtail butterfly whose larvae feed on citrus leaves, causing defoliation.
A scale insect that infests citrus and jujube trees, reducing plant vigor through sap feeding.
The citrus leafminer, a moth whose larvae tunnel into leaves, causing curling and damage.
A mite that affects olive trees, causing leaf distortion and reduced fruit production.
A white butterfly whose larvae feed on cruciferous crops, leading to significant leaf damage.
A larval pest that bores into pods of legumes, destroying seeds and reducing yield.
A broad mite that damages a wide range of plants, causing leaf curling and stunting.
A pest, likely a caterpillar, that feeds on foliage, causing damage to various crops.
The tobacco cutworm, a caterpillar that feeds on a wide range of crops, causing extensive damage.
The Comstock mealybug, a sap-feeding pest that affects fruits and ornamentals.
A longhorn beetle that bores into wood, damaging trees and woody crops.
A fly whose larvae bore into rice stems, causing dead hearts and reduced yield.
A moth pest that affects crops, with larvae feeding on leaves and stems.
The chili thrips, a tiny pest that damages leaves and buds of various plants.
The mango seed weevil, boring into mango seeds and reducing fruit quality.
A social insect that damages crops and wooden structures by feeding on cellulose.
A termite species that attacks crops and trees, causing structural damage.
A citrus fruit fly that lays eggs in fruit, leading to maggot damage and rot.
Tiny insects that feed on plant cells, causing silvering and distortion of leaves.
The black citrus aphid, a sap-sucking pest that affects citrus trees.
The brown citrus aphid, known for transmitting citrus tristeza virus.
The greenhouse whitefly, a pest of greenhouse crops, feeding on sap and spreading viruses.
The arrowhead scale, a pest of citrus, forming dark scales and weakening plants.
The grape phylloxera, a root-feeding aphid that devastates vineyards.
A longhorn beetle that bores into wood, damaging trees and woody crops.
A yellow-colored mite that feeds on plant sap, causing stippling and leaf drop.
A bug that feeds on alfalfa, piercing stems and leaves, reducing forage quality.
A tiny wasp that lays eggs in alfalfa seeds, destroying them and reducing seed yield.
A beetle whose larvae feed on alfalfa leaves, causing significant defoliation.
Small sap-sucking insects that weaken plants and transmit viruses across various crops.
A caterpillar that moves in large groups, devouring crops like grasses and grains.
A moth whose larvae bore into rice stems, causing dead hearts and yield loss.
A caterpillar pest of beets and other crops, feeding on leaves and stems.
A fly that lays eggs on beet leaves, with larvae causing mines and damage.
A weevil that feeds on beet roots and foliage, reducing crop quality.
A general term for various beetles that damage crops by feeding on leaves or roots.
An aphid that infests cereals and grasses, transmitting viruses and reducing yield.
A caterpillar that cuts young plants at the base, particularly affecting corn and vegetables.
A beetle that feeds on crops and can release toxic chemicals, damaging plants and livestock.
A caterpillar that bores into cotton bolls and other fruits, causing significant damage.
A sap-sucking pest of rice, causing hopper burn and transmitting viral diseases.
A caterpillar that feeds on cabbage and other crucifers, causing extensive leaf damage.
A leafhopper that feeds on plant sap, potentially affecting a range of crops.
A moth larva that bores into corn stalks and ears, reducing yield and quality.
A caterpillar that feeds on corn ears and other crops, causing direct damage to fruits.
A caterpillar that cuts young plants at the soil line, affecting a variety of crops.
An aphid that infests grains like wheat and barley, reducing yield and quality.
A migratory caterpillar that attacks a wide range of crops, including corn and grasses.
A caterpillar that feeds on flax buds and flowers, reducing seed production.
A small beetle that jumps like a flea, feeding on leaves and creating small holes.
A thrips species that damages grains, causing silvering and reduced grain quality.
A chewing insect that consumes leaves and stems of various crops, especially grasses.
A green aphid that infests cereals and grasses, causing yellowing and stunting.
The larval stage of beetles, feeding on roots and causing plant decline.
A larger species of cutworm that severs young plants at the base, affecting crops.
A blister beetle that feeds on legumes, damaging pods and foliage.
A mite with long legs that feeds on plant sap, causing stippling and webbing.
A blister beetle that feeds on crops, potentially toxic to livestock if ingested.
A moth whose larvae feed on grasses and crops, causing defoliation.
Tiny arachnids that feed on plant sap, causing stippling, yellowing, and webbing.
A burrowing insect that damages roots and tubers, disrupting plant growth.
A thrips species that feeds on plant cells, causing damage to legumes and other crops.
A pest, possibly a mite or insect, that affects crops by feeding on leaves or sap.
A maggot that bores into rice stems, causing dead hearts and reduced yield.
A clearwing moth whose larvae bore into tree trunks, weakening woody plants.
A moth larva that bores into peach tree trunks, causing gum exudation and death.
A redlegged earth mite that feeds on seedlings, causing significant early damage.
A common name for spider mites, feeding on plant sap and causing leaf stippling.
A midge whose larvae induce galls in rice plants, disrupting growth and yield.
A caterpillar that feeds on rice leaves, reducing photosynthesis and yield.
A moth larva that rolls rice leaves, feeding inside and causing damage.
A sap-sucking pest of rice, transmitting viruses and causing hopper burn.
A pest, possibly a snail or insect, that affects rice grains and shells.
A weevil whose larvae feed on rice roots, causing yellowing and reduced growth.
A wasp-like insect whose larvae feed on leaves, often defoliating trees and crops.
A beetle pest that likely affects crops by feeding on roots or foliage.
A small hopper that feeds on rice sap, causing hopper burn and yield loss.
A larval pest that bores into plant stems, disrupting nutrient flow and yield.
A bug that pierces and sucks sap from crops, causing wilting and fruit damage.
The spotted alfalfa aphid, a pest of legumes, causing yellowing and stunting.
A midge that attacks wheat flowers, reducing grain set and yield.
A thrips species that feeds on wheat, causing silvering and reduced grain quality.
A sawfly whose larvae bore into wheat stems, causing lodging and yield loss.
A rice pest with a white back, feeding on sap and transmitting viral diseases.
A moth with white-edged wings, whose larvae feed on foliage of various crops.
A small white insect that feeds on plant sap, spreading viruses and causing wilting.
The larval stage of click beetles, feeding on roots and tubers underground.
A yellowish caterpillar that cuts young plants at the base, affecting crop stands.
A moth larva that bores into rice stems, causing dead hearts and reduced yield.
